title: Erdős #650: Divisibility Covering in Intervals
description: If A ⊆ {1,...,N} with |A| = m, every interval of length 2N contains ≥ f(m) integers divisible by distinct elements of A. Known: f(m) ≫ √m. Open: Is f(m) ≪ √m?

overview.historicalContext: Erdős and Sarányi (1959) established the lower bound f(m) ≫ √m using a pigeonhole argument. The upper bound f(m) ≪ √m remains open. This problem connects divisibility, covering, and number-theoretic distribution.
overview.problemStatement: Let f(m) be such that if A ⊆ {1,...,N} has |A| = m, then every interval in [1,∞) of length 2N contains ≥ f(m) distinct integers b₁,...,bᵣ where each bᵢ is divisible by some aᵢ ∈ A, with all aᵢ distinct. Estimate f(m). Is f(m) ≪ m^{1/2}?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize valid sets, intervals, coverings with distinct witnesses, the function f(m), the Erdős-Sarányi lower bound, the open upper bound conjecture, small cases, divisibility structure, greedy algorithms, probabilistic approaches, extremal sets, related functions, and asymptotic analysis.
keyInsights: Upper bound f(m) ≤ C√m is OPEN
Each element a ∈ A contributes ~2N/a multiples to interval
Pigeonhole argument gives the lower bound
If both bounds hold, f(m) ~ √m asymptotically

conclusion.summary: This formalization captures Erdős Problem #650 on divisibility covering in intervals. The function f(m) measures minimum guaranteed coverings where each covered integer uses a distinct divisor from A. The lower bound √m is known; the upper bound remains open.
conclusion.implications: The problem connects divisibility theory with covering problems. The √m lower bound uses counting arguments, while the upper bound question relates to extremal set configurations and the distribution of multiples.
openQuestions: What is the structure of extremal sets achieving f(m)?
What are the exact values of f(m) for small m?
